title: A Quantum-Science-Ready Triel Atom
authors:
Putian Li, Xianquan Yu, Seth Hew Peng Chew, Jinchao Mo, Tiangao Lu,
  Travis L. Nicholson
abstract:
Ultracold gases of atoms from Main Group III (Group 13) of the Periodic
Table, also known as "triel elements," have great potential for a new
generation of quantum matter experiments. The first magneto-optical trap of a
triel element (indium) was recently realized, but more progress is needed
before a triel is ready for modern quantum science experiments. Cutting edge
quantum science can be performed with atoms that are cooled to the 10 uK level
or below, prepared in pure quantum states, and optically trapped. Here we
report the achievement of all three of these milestones in atomic indium.
First, we perform polarization gradient cooling of an indium gas to 15 uK.
Second, we spin polarize the gas into a single hyperfine sublevel of either the
$5P_{1/2}$ indium ground state or the $5P_{3/2}$ metastable state. Third, we
confine indium in a 1064 nm optical lattice, achieving a 3 s trap lifetime.
With these results, indium is now a candidate for a next generation quantum
research platform.
